Mr. J.F.A. Stott, Fairview Creek, received a visit by last mail from Mr. Murray Britton. Mr. Britton and Mr. Maclean visited Winnipeg on Monday last. They interviewed the Lieut. Governor and spoke of the high value of the medical exceptions they have from His Honor.
A cedar shell has just been built by Mr. Murray Britton, and will be used as a promenade by competent judges to test the skill of workmanship to be done by W.R. Fisher. The dimensions are Length, 23 ft.; width, 10 inches; depth, 9 inches. Winnipeg has now a builder of W.R. Fisher of this town.
It is expected that in a couple of weeks Lord Dufferin, Governor General, will visit this city. He has been here before, and the result was that he was met by a large crowd of people who came to see him. We think we should unite in making him feel very much at home. Our Council should be forward in this matter and do everything in its power to make him feel at home and comfortable. We have no hesitation in saying that should His Honour decide to pay us another visit, he will receive a very cordial welcome.
Some party started off after the other day near the height of the creek and subject to the current of the river. The result was that the boat was turned over and the result was that he was met by a large crowd of people who came to see him. People who are in harness ought to be taught, by legal process, that there is an obstruction in force preventing a boat from going up or down the river. I am not going to engage in anything when it has answered its legitimate purpose.

Here most, the anarchist, is now putting in practice in jail, the doctrines he has preached outside. He is bringing into the fold a host of perfect equality with thieves and ruined gentlemen of all grades of society. It is to be hoped he may prove a martyr to his principles.

The Emigrant speaking of the Manitoba and Northwestern Railway, says: "Its northern terminus will be Prince Albert, 450 miles west of present main Saskatchewan River. At present there are 150 miles of this road under operation, leaving 300 to be built. Fifty more miles will be in operation this fall. At the rate of fifty miles a year we shall have to wait five years before we hear the sound of the new horse whistling."

Because Senator O'Donohoe sold himself to the Conservative party for a banquet—a deal paid more than he was worth—and the banquet is not forthcoming, the Irish Canada does want its co-religionists disfranchised. We would recommend our Catholic friends to accede to the proposition at least so far as Senator O'Donohoe and Pat Boyle are concerned. It would go a great way in stopping the "present truculent system" inaugurated and carried on by O'Donohoe, Boyle & Co.

The bill respecting fishing by foreign vessels lately passed by the Dominion Parliament provides that any vessel which, after having entered Canadian waters, fails to comply with the laws of Canada or the United Kingdom, shall forfeit tackle, rigging, apparel, furniture, stores and cargo. Under this bill it will not be necessary to prove specific offenses.

James E. Steen, Secretary of the Winnipeg Board of Trade, in a recent article on Northwestern Trade, gives a good account of the Northwest containing 244 and upwards of business concerns, and says there are 249 other points throughout the Northwest with less than 25 traders in each. Since Prince Albert is not included among these figures, the impression likely to be created that we belong to the latter, and we beg to call Mr. Steen's attention to the fact that there are plenty places of business needing trading facilities in Prince Albert, and that while we would like to have railway connection, we are not like some other places in the Northwest, unable to exist without it.

There is not a doubt that the Northwest has a great future before it. The Pacific Railway has provided the main outlet and the imagination which is necessary, but the fertility of its soil will be the great attraction which will draw settlers to it. No doubt settlers will have some hardships to endure, and no doubt many will be fitted for agricultural life and these will fail. But on the whole, the settlers are pleased with the country and confident of their success in it. Their hardships are not so severe as those of the early settlers in Ontario, and the whole period through which they must pass will be short. The Ontario pioneer was forced to clear his land before he could cultivate it, and he had to make a living out of it before he could hope to live in anything like comfort. The Northwest settler has just to take over a year or two and then all is plain sailing before him.

Hamilton Spectator.

While Canadians have been staggered on many occasions by the lamentable ignorance which some prominent journalists display of Canada and Canadian affairs, it is a pleasure to us to be able to find one (the Editor) able to speak intelligently and truthfully of "how they manage it in Canada." In its issue of May 11th, review the history of Canada under consideration, giving the causes which led to the union, and concludes: "It only remains to be said that by federation the struggling colonies of North America have been united, and the prosperous backwoodsmen thereafter have seen a success both politically, socially and commercially, and that the Dominion is now making rapid strides in the development of her resources, which, when they come to play place her amongst the nations of the world, always, we hope and believe, under the British flag, of which her sons are admittedly so proud."

MISTAKEN SYMPATHY.

Says Le Presse: "Louis Riel was hanged on November 16th. His newborn infant died in its mother's arms. This will be the turn of the mother, who has already lost her son, surely. Surely the vengeance of the Orange lodges incited by Sir John Macdonald and by the French Canadian press, which has been the bane of the country, is by this act glutted. Is not the ruin of the unfortunate race of French and Catholic halfbreeds, which they have determined to root out of the North-west, simply because it is French and Catholic, now complete? Whilst the wretched widow was lying in agony on her deathbed, thinking of him who is no more, and of her poor fatherless child left friendless in the world, the Parliament of Quebec, urged by our Ministers to show its devotion to Sir John and Sir Hector, refused to express the slightest regret over the death of Red River, the death of a race which had finally been doomed to dishonor its memory."

This is very touching, but is not likely to awake much sympathy in the hearts of those who knew the late lamented deceased, chief of the Metis. There is no cause for a vote for poor outraged humanity can fail to have sympathy for his mother, wife and children. It is, fortunately, seldom that a family in the Northwest become bereft of both husband and father, an act which makes a protector, as was Louis Riel. He was the personification of beggary of allness, while at the same time he was a tyrant, who exercised the most outrageous and atheistic powers to force his brother Metis to join him in the endeavor to defy the Government, and he more than any other man, is responsible for the ruin of the French half breed race. We do not sympathize with him. Well, we mistake very much the temper of the French of Lower Canada if they are to be influenced by such appeals to vote against Sir John Macdonald. We only intervene with regard to Riel was not hang him when he first rebelled. It would have saved a great deal of trouble, and the Metis of the South Branch would have been spared the humiliation which he brought upon them.

But the strongest feature in this endeavor to arouse opposition to the Government of Sir John Macdonald is the course pursued by the Globe. We can understand the Globe opposing Sir John Macdonald grounds. That is its business. But when we find a prominent journalist shedding tears of sympathy for a creature who richly deserved hanging, we confess it astonishes us. His Le Globe is a daily newspaper to shout for the murdered people of Frog Lake, no tears of sympathy for the gallant boys who laid down their lives in defense of their flag? Has it no tears of sympathy for the widows and orphans of those brave parents whose sorrow was brought about by the machinations of Riel and his lieutenants? No, apparent none. It is too busy shedding tears over the death of a man who damaged his own house by burning it, friends, a curse to his people, and who deserved as richly to die as the murderer of Hon. Thomas D'Arcy McGee. The needs of the Liberal party must be great when its organs are unable to seek such tactics as these.

Col. Schreiber, representing the Dominion government, on June 8th landed a party of 80 lumbermen at Wood Mountain with a large party to establish head-quarters, and make preparations for the opening of their ranch, which is located in the immediate vicinity of this post. They have run on route from Hay River, and will be here in a few days to be followed in a short time by an additional ten thousand. They propose to bring in a total of twenty-six thousand acres of land, and a house of seven hundred thousand acres for twenty-one years. They express themselves highly satisfied with the country as a grazing district.

THE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE.

A Buffalo Ranch to be Started.

The Winnipeg Sun says: "Major Bell, the famous Bell farm, is the Queen's own sheep ranch. 'Every thing on the farm looks splendid,' he said. 'I never in any previous year saw anything to equal the condition of the sheep. They will be shipped out in two weeks.'

"What about the proposed agricultural college?"

"Well, Prof. Tanner, who is to have charge of it is now in England to obtain students and experience in agricultur- al studies so that it will be quite a large institution. Prof. Tanner and an assistant will conduct the college and instruction will be given in practical and theoretical farming. A small sum will be charged students for board and room. If successful it will be a great success and will be the means of inducing many young Englishmen and others to come to Canada and settle here, receiving a thorough training in the old college."

"I noticed in the Sun last night," continued the Major, "a paragraph about a man in Texas who was starting a buffalo ranch. I thought it was a good and excellent idea. I was specially interested in it, as a number of acres near my place would make a good buffalo ranch near Winnipeg. We have purchased Capt. Robson's herd of buffaloes and will start a fine farm there. We will get some good cows or fine bullocks and cross them with buffaloes, and will try to bring to the country a superior breed of thoroughbred cattle."

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

FORT MCLEOD.

From the Gazette.

Church destroyed. (Expressed) Fort McLeod, was destroyed by fire on the 2nd inst. It was the finest church in the diocese of Saskatchewan. The total loss is estimated at between £1,000 and £2,000. Immediate steps are being taken to build a new church.

Police officer. Colville, after serving one year's sentence in the police guard room for stealing a revolver, escaped last night. He bored through the bars of his cell. A party has gone in pursuit.

REGINA.

From the Leader.

The Long Lake Railway was opened on the 7th inst., for traffic to Carman, a distance of twenty-five miles. About fifty people took advantage of an invitation extended by Mr. G. R. Popple to take a trip over the line. The party started about five o'clock in the evening to take dinner at the Palmer House. Traveling by dog sleds, they returned to Mr. Popple's on his enterprise. Traveling will be completed to Long Lake this week, when a boat will be put on the lake opening up a new route to Battleford.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin.

Presbyterian churches are being erected at Beaver Bar and Fort Saskatchewan. The Edmonton congregation three churches are to be built and commodious log buildings erected. Work will commence early in the spring. An Indian mission school has also been established at the Stanley Plains Reserve.

A considerable drop in the price of fur is reported.

Traveling will be started. About two weeks later than last year.

E. Rossellow has two stables by fire on Friday of last week.

J. Colburn lost his stable by fire on Friday of last week.

Clark's Gunsmith, June 12th. The old gunsmith shop used by the people of Saskatchewan from the military authorities last year, and the wire cage given them by ten men, was destroyed by fire caused by a spark by the blacksmiths. The result in Prince Albert has just decided in favor of the gunsmiths.

S. H. Kerr, of Winnipeg, passed yesterday raising a large which was sunk in the river near the elbow on the way across the water. The contents dry and clean are suffering.

Mr. E. T. Galt, accompanied by a party of friends from Montreal, has gone on a visit to the west coast of Canada.

The cricket teams are practically over, and we are now engaged in collecting funds from Medicine Hat on the 1st of July.

TOWN COUNCIL.

An adjourned meeting of the Council was held in the Council Chamber on Monday evening.

Present: Coms. Brown, Ratcliff, and Macdonald.

On motion of Coms. Brown and Ratcliff, Com. Goodfellow took the chair.

The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted.

A communication was received from W. H. Taylor, Town Solicitor, re col- lector's bonds.

A by-law for the expanding of Rev- erend Thomas' improvements was in- troduced by Com. Ratcliff.

The Council went into Committee of the Whole to consider by law for Re- v. Thomas' improvements and bonds, with Com. Ratcliff in the chair.

The by-law was considered clause by clause.

The Committee rose and the Chairman reported accordingly.

The by-law was then read a third time and passed, and ordered to be signed and numbered.

The by-law to amend by law No. 1 re- lating to the inspectors was read a second time.

The Council went into Committee of the Whole to consider by law to amend by law No. 1, Com. Brown in the chair.

The by-law was considered and adopt- ed, and ordered to be signed and numbered, and on motion was ordered to be signed and numbered.

The by-law Regulating Transient Traders was read a second time.

The by-law Regulating the Regula- tion of Fire Departments was read a second time.

Moved by Com. Brown, seconded by Com. Ratcliff, that the by-law for Re- v. Thomas' improvements be not read a third time.

Com. Ratcliff was authorized to get the necessary permits for draining sloughs between 3rd street and River.

The Council then adjourned.
